name: Sudden oak death
summary: Sudden oak death is a forest disease caused by the water mold Phytophthora ramorum, affecting a variety of trees and shrubs, most notably oaks. It leads to the rapid decline and death of trees, primarily impacting coastal oak woodlands.

cause_of_disease.describe: A pathogen that infects the leaves and bark of trees, disrupting the flow of nutrients and causing cankers.
The disease thrives in wet, cool environments where the pathogen can spread more easily.
Transportation of infected plants, soil, and water can lead to the spread of the disease to new areas.

steps: Implement restrictions on the movement of infected plants and soil.
Clean tools and equipment to prevent the spread of pathogens.
Apply fungicides to prevent the spread, targeting susceptible areas.
Ensure repeated applications as recommended for effectiveness.
Remove and destroy infected trees to limit further spread.
Monitor surrounding area for new signs of infection.

tips: Monitor trees regularly for early signs of infection such as foliage discoloration and bark lesions.
Increase airflow around trees by spacing plantings and pruning lower branches.
Educate community and stakeholders about disease identification and management practices.
